div.h1: Context Switch: Register Save/Restore Assembly Flow
div.h3: Why C Cannot Do This Every Byte Accounted For

div.p: Color Semantics Red = hot path / danger Green = success / safe resume Yellow = transition / caution Blue = data read Purple = metadata / PCB fields Gray = padding / unused / discarded

g.text: Why context_switch() CANNOT Be Written in C
Kernel Stack State at Each Assembly Step
RESTORE SEQUENCE Resuming the Next Process
Fake Initial Stack Frame Starting a Brand-New Process

p.strong: C Compiler's Register Contract (System V x86 ABI)

div.p: Caller-saved (EAX, ECX, EDX): Caller saves BEFORE call if it needs them C context_switch() is FREE to trash these Interrupted process NEVER saved them before IRQ
Callee-saved (EBX, ESI, EDI, EBP): Callee MUST restore these on return C compiler auto-generates push/pop for these 4 only
EFLAGS: NEVER saved by any C calling convention ESP: C has no syntax to save/restore stack pointer EIP: Implicit in call/ret wrong for context switch CS/DS: C cannot emit segment register saves

p.strong: The Gap: What C Saves vs What We Need

div.p:
Register C Saves? We Need? Gap?
EAX (caller) SILENT CORRUPTION ECX (caller) SILENT CORRUPTION EDX (caller) SILENT CORRUPTION EBX (callee) OK ESI (callee) OK EDI (callee) OK EBP (callee) OK EFLAGS NEVER INTERRUPT FLAG LOST ESP implicit STACK POINTER LOST EIP via ret (wrong) WRONG RESUME POINT

Bug manifestation: Resumed process uses EAX expecting its saved value, gets scheduler's intermediate result. Failure is 10,000+ instructions AFTER the switch. No crash. Wrong answer. Impossible to debug.

g.text: struct pcb { ... } offsets for asm addressing

div.p: Critical: kernel_esp at offset +0x30 is the only field context_switch_asm reads/writes directly via [reg + 0x30]. All other fields are restored from the STACK the kernel_esp points to.

text.tspan: STEP 0: Stack when context_switch() is called

g.text: STEP 2: pushad Save All 8 General-Purpose Registers
STEP 3: Save Current Kernel ESP PCB.kernel_esp
STEP 4: Load Next Process's Kernel ESP Pivot the Stack
STEP 4.5: CR3 Reload Switch Address Space (if different)
STEP 5: popad Restore Next Process's 8 GPRs
STEP 7: ret Jump to Next Process's Saved EIP
Cycle Cost per Operation (2 GHz CPU = 0.5ns per cycle)
popad restore 8 GPRs from next stack
TLB cold misses on first access in new address space

p.strong: Why most cycles are memory latency, not computation:

ul.li: pushad / popad touch the kernel stack L1 if hot, DRAM if cold (10ms since last access)
Loading pcb->kernel_esp L3 or DRAM (PCB last touched 10ms ago at 100Hz scheduler)
First memory access after CR3 reload guaranteed TLB miss 3 page-table reads
The 10 assembly instructions are ~15 cycles; the 485+ cycles are waiting for RAM

div.p: This is why Go goroutines switch in ~100ns: no CR3 reload (shared address space), smaller register set, hot stacks from frequent switching.

A new process has never run it has no "saved state from previous preemption." We manufacture a fake stack frame that looks exactly like what pushad+pushfd+IRQ would have left. When the scheduler first selects it, popad restores zeros for GPRs, popfd restores IF=1, ret jumps to the trampoline, and iret jumps to the entry function.

g.text: Current Process Kernel Stack (ESP growing downward )

text.tspan: EIP at esp+12 is where interrupted process resumes.

g.text: ; STEP 1: Save EFLAGS contains IF (interrupt flag!)
; C calling convention NEVER does this.
; If IF is lost, resumed process runs with interrupts OFF forever.

text.tspan: WHY: EFLAGS contains the Interrupt Flag (bit 9).
If we restore EFLAGS without this, the resumed
process runs with interrupts DISABLED system hang.

g.text: ; STEP 2: Save all 8 general-purpose registers atomically.
; pushad pushes: EAX, ECX, EDX, EBX, ESP(pre-push), EBP, ESI, EDI
; Encoding: PUSHAD = 0x60 (single opcode, 8 pushes = 32 bytes total)
pushad ; ESP -= 32; all 8 GPRs on stack

text.tspan: WHY pushad instead of individual pushes?
Atomic: no interrupt can fire between saves.
EAX/ECX/EDX included these are the registers

g.text: ; STEP 3: Record WHERE on the kernel stack all our saved
; state lives. Future resume needs this to find EFLAGS, GPRs, EIP.
; [esp+36+4] because: 32 bytes pushad + 4 bytes pushfd = 36 bytes
; above our current ESP; then +4 for the call's return address.
; We want to save the ESP *before* the call instruction pushed ret addr.
; Simpler: just save current ESP the resume path restores from here.
mov eax, [esp + 36 + 4] ; Load *current_pcb ptr (arg1, past our pushes)
; Offset 0x30 = kernel_esp field in PCB struct

ul.li: esp+36 = return address (pushed by call context_switch_asm)

div.p: After mov [eax+0x30], esp: The current PCB's kernel_esp field contains the stack address where EDI is stored. To resume current: mov esp, pcb->kernel_esp then popad then popfd then ret lands at saved EIP.

g.text: ; After this line, we are on the NEXT process's kernel stack.
; All subsequent memory accesses go to next's saved state.
; The current process is now "frozen" unreachable until scheduled.
; Must load arg2 BEFORE changing ESP (arg2 is at [esp+44]).
; WE ARE NOW ON NEXT'S STACK

text.tspan: Reading [esp+N] accesses NEXT process's saved registers
The CPU is executing kernel code belonging to 'current'
but with next's stack pointer a deliberate hybrid state
Duration: exactly 4 more instructions until iret completes the switch

g.text: ; Only if next process has a different page directory.
; Kernel threads share boot_page_directory skip for them.
cmp eax, [ecx + 0x34] ; Compare current CR3 to next->page_dir
je .same_pgdir ; Skip flush if same (kernel threads)
mov cr3, [ecx + 0x34] ; Load next's page directory physical addr

text.tspan: CR3 flush cost: ~30 cycles reload + subsequent TLB misses
(each miss = 3 memory reads for 2-level page walk = ~60-180ns).
Kernel threads skip this use PAGE_GLOBAL flag on kernel PTEs
so TLB entries survive CR3 reloads when switching between

g.text: ; STEP 5: popad restores 8 GPRs from the NEXT process's stack.
; These values were pushed by the PREVIOUS invocation of pushad
; when next was last preempted (or were set up as the fake initial frame).
; popad pops: EDI, ESI, EBP, (ESP ignored), EBX, EDX, ECX, EAX
; Note: popad does NOT restore ESP from the stack value at esp+12.
; The hardware skips that slot to keep ESP consistent.
popad ; ESP += 32; all 8 GPRs NEXT PROCESS's values
Next Process's Stack values being restored
Next's EFLAGS (after popad esp points here)
; STEP 6: Restore EFLAGS MUST include IF=1 for preemptible process.
; After this: the CPU's condition codes, direction flag, and interrupt
; enable bit are all exactly what they were when next was preempted.
popfd ; ESP += 4; EFLAGS next process's saved EFLAGS
; IF is now restored: interrupts enabled if they were

text.tspan: IF (Interrupt Flag) in EFLAGS is bit 9.
If next process was running normal code: IF=1 (interrupts on).
If next process was in a cli/sti critical section: IF=0.
popfd atomically restores the EXACT state no gap where
interrupts could incorrectly fire between restore steps.

g.text: ; STEP 7: 'ret' pops EIP from the stack and jumps there.
; The value on the stack is the return address that was placed
; when context_switch_asm was 'call'ed during next's PREVIOUS preemption.
; For a brand-new process: the fake initial frame has the entry point here.
; This is not a 'jmp' it uses the stack. The stack currently contains
; exactly the return address back into irq_dispatcher (or trampoline),
; which will then 'iret' to restore CS, EIP, EFLAGS (ring transition).
; CPU jumps to: irq_common_stub exit sequence
; which executes 'iret' final restore of CS+EIP+EFLAGS

text.tspan: After 'ret': execution is in irq_common_stub's exit sequence.
EIP where next process was interrupted
EFLAGS (already restored by popfd, but iret re-restores from frame)
[ESP, SS] only if crossing ring boundary (ring 3 process)
The process resumes at the exact instruction it was at.
behaves identically to real saved frame
